definition: tight/strict/close at hand/near/urgent/tense/hard up/short of money/to tighten
good-looking/charming/(of goods) in great demand/(coll.) to season (food)

sentences.english: In China's big cities, real estate's expensive and young women are in short supply.
sentences.chinese: 中国的大城市，房价高企，年轻女子的行市紧俏。

sentences.english: You should buy this bicycle while there are some left, it is in great demand.
sentences.chinese: 趁着还有，你应该买下这部自行车，它是紧俏商品。

sentences.english: A market place where illegal or hard-to-get items are sold or where money is illegally exchanged.
sentences.chinese: 非法或紧俏物资的销售点，或者非法换汇的地方。

sentences.english: Keep rare items back for customers who would pay the best prices.
sentences.chinese: 把紧俏商品留给肯出大价钱的主顾们。

sentences.english: At a time of tight budgets, many schools are finding that offer too good to refuse.
sentences.chinese: 在眼下预算紧俏时期，很多学校难以拒绝这一支持。

sentences.english: The declarant certified personnel integrates the world along with the Chinese economy, but is scarcer.
sentences.chinese: 报关员持证人员随着中国经济融入世界而更加紧俏。

sentences.english: Air or train tickets to Heilongjiang are in huge demand.
sentences.chinese: 目前，前往黑龙江的机票或火车票都很紧俏。

sentences.english: A market place where illegal or hard-to-get items are sold or where money is illegal exchanged.
sentences.chinese: 非法或紧俏物资的销售点，或者非法换汇的地方。

sentences.english: Eider down clothes of novel design have Been in short supply this winter.
sentences.chinese: 设计新颖的羽绒系列服装，成为今冬的紧俏货。

sentences.english: I would like to see the samples first.
sentences.chinese: 要知道这些商品很紧俏。

sentences.english: Flags were in such demand, they were stolen.
sentences.chinese: 商店里，国旗是如此紧俏，有人不惜偷抢。

sentences.english: Pumps and generators has become a tight natural merchandise.
sentences.chinese: 水泵和发电机自然成了紧俏商品。

sentences.english: With an aging baby boomer generation, healthcare continues to make a strong showing.
sentences.chinese: 随着婴儿潮一代进入老年，保健行业依然保持紧俏。

definition: (a product) sells well/to be in demand
very short of (food, clean water etc)/extreme shortage/deficit
lit. many monks and not much gruel (idiom)/fig. not enough to go around/demand exceeds supply
